name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: @morganranstrom @LizSimmie The only way to assess impact of new technology is by comparison. Building a hospital uses more resources than building a yacht; that doesn't make it worse.  It's indeed possible that EVs are bad bc of how electricity is generated. But comparing EVs to BTC doesn't seem meaningful

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: @AdviserCounsel Ha, I’ve got to start posting them again. Had something from the Canary Islands on Sunday.

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: @LizSimmie Yeah, I'm open to the argument that EVs are not as green as some think due to manufacture, battery mining, etc. But the comparison to a regular car (or to public transport!) is the right one.

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: I agree, with a caveat.  If AUM isn't best metric for your biz, okay. But then you must present alt figures in a regular & verifiable way. Otherwise how can people judge your growth based on anything other than AUM on ADV? Crowing about a one-off vanity metric doesn't cut it.

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: @LizSimmie EVs are an alternative to gas-powered cars. Bitcoin is an alternative to baseball cards. Since gas-powered cars are much worse for the environment than baseball cards, having an alternative to the former is more important than having an alternative to the latter.

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: @Mike_Thrasher But your earlier story says that the $800m has been committed and is being onboarded. Onboarding assets doesn't take 11 months.   To put it very simply, was $800m being onboarded in May, or was $800m not being onboarded in May? If it was, why hasn't it shown up in their ADV yet?

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: Here's a strange one.  In May Vise said it had $800m "committed to the platform from RIAs, meaning they have signed discretionary manager agreements and are currently being onboarded" per RIAIntel.  Vise's new ADV reports just $144m AUM.  Did onboarding fail? Or was $800m a lie?

name: Alex Rosenberg
tweet: New year's resolution for the RIA press: Let's stop calling RIAs 'market-beating' based on results of a single portfolio, especially where it's a model (that is, not real) portfolio, especially where results are backfilled after this portfolio's best year ever.
